results.abstract: Every week, we’ll bring you stories that capture the wonders of the human body, nature and the cosmos.

results.title: ‘It’s Crazy’: The Scramble for Ancient Treasures After Ukraine’s Dam Disaster
results.abstract: After the Kakhovka dam was blown up in June, the reservoir above it quickly drained, revealing a bonanza of artifacts that has electrified Ukrainian archaeologists.
results.byline: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Finbarr O’Reilly

multimedia.copyright: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times

results.title: Medical Group Backs Youth Gender Treatments, but Calls for Research Review
results.abstract: The American Academy of Pediatrics renewed its support of gender care for minors while commissioning a fresh look at the evidence.

results.title: Leprosy May Be Endemic in Central Florida, Scientists Report
results.abstract: Still, there are fewer than 200 cases nationally each year, and the numbers have fallen significantly from the peak decades ago.

multimedia.caption: Leprosy, also known as Hansen’s disease, is caused by slow-growing bacteria called Mycobacterium leprae. About 95 percent of people are genetically resistant to the bacteria.
multimedia.copyright: Steve Gschmeissner/Science Source

results.title: Amid Signs of a Covid Uptick, Researchers Brace for the ‘New Normal’
results.abstract: Infections remain very low, despite signs of a slight increase. Now, experts are looking for clues to what living with the coronavirus will be like this winter and beyond.

multimedia.caption: Nearly all Americans have built up multiple layers of immunity following repeated infections, immunizations or both, so the virus is unlikely to cause the harm this winter that was seen in previous seasons.
multimedia.copyright: Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times

results.title: Alan Roland, 93, Psychoanalyst Who Cautioned Against Western Bias, Dies
results.abstract: In “In Search of Self” and other books, he emphasized the role of cultural influences in a patient’s life.
des_facet: In Search of Self in India and Japan: Toward a Cross-Cultural Psychology (Book)

multimedia.caption: Alan Roland in Phoenix in 2011. He brought new insights to psychoanalysis with a cross-cultural view.

results.title: NASA’s Voyager 2 Is Out of Contact but Not Lost in Space
results.abstract: The aging spacecraft’s antenna was misdirected by a glitch, although officials say the distant probe appears to be functioning as intended.

multimedia.caption: The Voyager 2 spacecraft, seen here being worked on by NASA engineers in 1977, has traveled more than 12 billion miles from Earth.
multimedia.copyright: NASA/JPL-Caltech

results.title: It’s Official: Stores Can No Longer Sell Most Incandescent Lights
results.abstract: New efficiency rules, more than a decade in the making, have taken effect, relegating Edison’s glowing orbs to the history books.

multimedia.caption: Under the new rules, the Department of Energy estimated that Americans will collectively save billions of dollars on utility bills.
multimedia.copyright: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Under the new rules, the Department of Energy estimated that Americans will collectively save billions of dollars on utility bills.

results.title: Saving Lives at the Grand Canyon, One Salty Snack at a Time
results.abstract: In a summer of deadly heat for hikers in the Southwest, rangers at Grand Canyon National Park use a pioneering approach of aggressive messaging and outreach to prevent disaster on the trails.

multimedia.caption: In a recent training exercise, a Grand Canyon National Park staffer practiced maneuvering a loaded stretcher up and over the canyon rim. While search-and-rescue incidents across the National Park system have ticked upward alongside rising visitation in recent years, that’s not the case at the Grand Canyon.
multimedia.copyright: NPS Photo/J. Stebbins

multimedia.caption: In a recent training exercise, a Grand Canyon National Park staffer practiced maneuvering a loaded stretcher up and over the canyon rim. While search-and-rescue incidents across the National Park system have ticked upward alongside rising visitation in recent years, that’s not the case at the Grand Canyon.

results.title: Scenes From a City That Only Hands Out Tickets for Using Fentanyl
results.abstract: Oregon’s experiment to curb overdoses by decriminalizing small amounts of illicit drugs is in its third year, and life has changed for most everyone in the city of Portland.
results.byline: By Jordan Gale and Jan Hoffman

multimedia.caption: Portland emergency responders treating a person overdosing on fentanyl at an R.V. parked on a residential street.

results.title: Mauricio Diazgranados Is a Botanist in a Hurry
results.abstract: For the first time, the New York Botanical Garden has a chief scientist who hails from the same region as so much of its collections.

multimedia.caption: “This is the time for institutions like N.Y.B.G. to start providing solutions to the world,” said Mauricio Diazgranados, chief science officer of the New York Botanical Garden. “We just cannot keep doing the science as we are used to doing.”
multimedia.copyright: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times

results.title: Is It an E-Bike, or a Motorcycle for Children?
results.abstract: With a throttle and no pedals, Super73’s new “electric balance bike” blurs the lines of regulation and safety. “No license, registration or insurance required,” its marketing promises.

results.title: A Theory of Childbirth’s Evolution May Not Be What You’re Expecting
results.abstract: Scientists are revisiting an influential theory that the evolution of big brains made human childbirth risky.

results.title: ‘A Dangerous Combination’: Teenagers’ Accidents Expose E-Bike Risks
results.abstract: The e-bike industry is booming, but many vehicles are not legal for teenagers, and accidents are on the rise.

results.title: What Is an E-Bike, and How Safe Are They?
results.abstract: Surprisingly tricky questions about an increasingly popular vehicle.

results.title: Louise Levy, Who Was Studied for Her Very Long Life, Is Dead at 112
results.abstract: She was one of hundreds of people, all of them Ashkenazi Jews, whose good health and cognitive ability at extreme old age were the subject of genetic research.

multimedia.caption: Louise Levy credited her longevity in part to her low-cholesterol diet, positive attitude and a daily glass of red wine.

results.title: A Bottleneck on the Grid Threatens Clean Energy. New Rules Aim to Help.

results.title: Blood of Young Mice Extends Life in the Old

results.title: King Charles Doesn’t Have as Many Swans as He Used to
results.abstract: For hundreds of years, the royal family has laid claim to many of England’s swans. An annual count found a worrisome drop in cygnets along a stretch of the River Thames this year.
per_facet: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
